B000093NLH|5.0|This CD was quite a surprise --- actually, I shouldn't say that I was surprised because I find everything that the Scorpions do as wonderfully creative and entertaining.  This CD, however, really shows the Scorpions at their best in many respects.  They are indeed a rock band -- in my opinion, the BEST rock band -- but on this outing they prove that they don't need amps and power chords to get their message across.  What you get instead is pure Scorpions glory.  Songs such as \\"Holiday\\" and \\"Still Loving You\\" have been rearranged as total acoustic numbers and they are absolutely gorgeous.  I don't know that I will ever be able to listen to \\"Holiday\\" any other way from now on.  The band covers \\"Dust in the Wind\\" and they blow Kansas away -- which is really saying something.  The song literally brought tears to my eyes.<br />The music fabulously showcases the songwriting talents of Rudolf and Klaus and the fantastic musical abilities of the entire band.  The acoustic guitars are backed up by subtle drumming, a cellist, bass guitar and keyboards.  It is almost a cross between their \\"plugged\\" music and the Berlin Orchestra Concert.  Without the power normally generated through their amps, the Scorpions show us what they are all about -- good music.  These guys aren't just rockers -- they are first class musicians (obviously classically trained) and the melodies are entrancing.  I guarantee that true Scorpions fans will be almost moved to tears with the sheer beauty of the instruments \\"singing together\\" in perfect harmony.<br />I get upset reading reviews that say \\"the Scorpions went downhill\\" or they \\"sold old\\" and changed their style.  Those reviewers are not Scorpions fans -- they are fans of particular songs.  True Scorpions fans understand that these guys have music flowing through their veins and they have not pigeon-holed themselves into one specific genre.  They write from their hearts and play from their souls -- and that will understandably generate different types of music.  To love the BAND (rather than just a particular song style) is to understand what they are saying to you through their music -- and to respond back to them in turn.  I can't think of a single Scorpions song that I do not like on some level because I understand what they are trying to say with their music.  They are saying \\"Here I am .. this is me\\" and when they bare their souls like that, who could NOT be moved by it?

B000001FOL|4.0|This is the first Nico album I ever bought, and in many ways it is still my favorite. \\"Chelsea Girl\\" is a beautiful document of the sixties chanteuse married with the underworld. Think Marianne Faithfull as a sixties singer of hip pop melded with her wisened and world weary recordings of the late 70's and 80's. Nico sings a unique mix of ballads (the Jackson Browne/Gregory Copeland penned \\"The Fairest of the Seasons\\", along with Browne's \\"These Days\\" and \\"Somewhere There's A Feather\\") and VU detached character sketches (\\"Little Sister\\", <BR>\\"Chelsea Girls\\"). The subject matter ranges from youthful hope and poetic observations on life, to harrowing tales of overdose and sex fantasy. All this is conveyed without judgement or opinion. Nico's own detached persona is evident even on her earliest works.<BR>The Velvet Underground members Lou Reed, John Cale and Sterling Morrison provided a very strong presence on the recording. Writing five of the tracks in one form or another, with Nico also in on \\"It Was a Pleasure Then\\", the sound they created as a band is conveyed here, also. Cale's chamber arrangements on many tracks brings out the poetic optimism of the Browne tracks especially. \\"And do I really have a hand in my forgetting? Yes and the morning has me looking in your eyes and seeing mine\\". These are tracks that didn't really fit VU, but for Nico they seem perfect.   <BR>     The title track takes on the tales of exotic trysts that occured at the Chelsea Hotel. Here the girls were objects of the fantasies of men with very creative and demanding imaginations. Margaret in foil, dear Ondine, (\\"she wants to be...a human being\\". \\"Here they come now. See them run now. Chelsea Girls\\"). It is truly an amazing track, and at over seven minutes there's time for many wonderous tales.<BR>     I also like her version of Dylan's \\"I'll Keep It With Mine\\". A lyric that good is hard to go wrong with. The distanced Dylan was an early favorite figure in America for Nico (\\"She  looked like she walked out of 'La Dolce Vita'.\\"). The simple arrangement puts the emphasis on the words and nice melody.<BR>     The last two tracks together with \\"It was a Pleasure Then\\" feel much akin to each other for me. The hope of the Jackson Browne songs is gone. Instead, there is loss, morbid resolution, and sorrow. \\"Wrap your troubles in dreams/ Send them all away\\". \\"It was a Pleasure Then\\" leaves us with a soul dwelling over what once was, and the skeletal remains of what is left. <BR>The ending track, written by the great Tim Hardin, is an elegy to another influential figure for Nico. \\"Eulogy for Lenny Bruce\\" (not \\"Ballad of Lenny Brown\\" as Modernist in a post modernist world wrote it, at least look at what you're writing about, poser) is just that. \\"I've lost a friend and I don't know why. But never again will we get together to die\\". Hardin's own enslavement to the needle and the damage done by it fueled a kinship he felt with Bruce, along with his refusal to bend or sell-out to censors. I've listend to this song many times, and feel that it works in many ways for many people and points in life. Such subject matter, and the slow cadence of the album as a whole, may seem depressing or unattractive for some. I feel that these elements simply make it an adult recording with much to offer for those brave enough to give it a chance. <BR>Try \\"Chelsea Girl\\", then get \\"The Marble Index\\", Nico's greatest artistic work. This is beautiful art by an often misunderstood and dismissed artist.
B00005JGAB|5.0|The debut Ramones album reigns as my personal favorite, although all their other 70s recordings come in a close 2nd place. 0800128052|5.0|So what's a guy to do?  He has no money, lousy high school grades, and zero size and athletic ability, yet his dream is to play football for the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame.  Again, what to do?<br />Never give up on your dream.<br />Director David Anspaugh's wonderful RUDY is one of the most inspiring films I've ever seen.  Based on a true story, Rudy Ruettiger (played by Sean Astin, forever more known to me as Samwise Gamgee) is a blue collar kid with a stubborn streak as wide as the chip on his shoulder.  Rudy's family and high school teachers scoff at his dream of going to Notre Dame, yet the young man perseveres.  He enrolls at a junior college, applies again and again for admission to the university--applications that are subsequently denied--yet he perseveres.  With no place to live he befriends the head of the maintenance crew at the stadium (played wonderfully by Charles Dutton) and ultimately sleeps in the maintenance office, yet he perseveres.  And when he finally gets accepted to Notre Dame--when he walks on to the Fighting Irish's storied football program and gets the stuffing beat out him, day after day--he perseveres to the film's magical, magnificent ending, an ending that signifies his perseverance has paid off.<br />This is a &quot;feel good&quot; movie that will make you stand up and cheer.  With unwavering respect and detail to Notre Dame tradition, RUDY delivers an inspirational story guaranteed to put a lump in your throat.  In fact, by the time the movie is over I'm crying more than the day I was born--and I'm looking for a pair of shoulder pads to put on and a tackling dummy to obliterate.  Strong set 48 toss sweep:  let's go!<br />--D. Mikels

0345457684|4.0|OK, this review is a bit of revisionist history.  Had I reviewed this book immediately after reading it, I probably would have emphasized it's strengths: the fine writing, the able characterisation, the superb visionary descriptions of his future Earth, and his fun assimilation of film noir into hard SF.  I also would have tossed in quite a few complaints about the derivative nature of some of his key plot points.  Without going into it with too much detail (and therefor saving the reader from spoilers) Morgan treads ground already covered (and covered better) by fellow UK writers Ken Macleod and Alastair Reynolds.  There's also a bit too much Blade Runner and Neuromancer here -- don't get me wrong, I love those seminal works.  Nevertheless, we've seen it all done before, and (to be repetitive) done better.<br />So... fast forward to today, and I firmly believe that this book is a must-read.  Why?  Because it sets up what is evidently going to become one of the most read and beloved future-universe space opera sagas of the decade.  I finished Morgan's sequel, Broken Angels, and let me tell you: it is fantastic.  It is as original as Altered Carbon is derivative.  The seemingly-throwaway lines in this book that so intrigued me come to glorious fruition in the sequel.  And as I know that this is supposed to be a review of Altered Carbon and not its unpublished (in the US) sequel, I'll just add that the new one is firmly well-written military SF, giving rise to the speculation that Morgan intends to mine the various sub-genres of SF, utilizing thier various strengths to advance what is obviously becoming an intensely spiritual story.<br />If you want to appreciate the masterpiece that is Morgan's new book, Altered Carbon is essential.  The author gives no quarter to the new reader unaquainted with the conceipts of his continuing universe, and you will be lost without it.  Plus, this is indeed one fine and entertaining read.<br />Check out Altered Carbon, and watch Richard K. Morgan become one of the bright shining stars in the already luminous UK SF scene.

0375414932|4.0|I was not familiar with William Boyd's work and picked up this novel because it sounded intriguing.  It is an exceptional book, managing to be at once a moving personal story, a brief (and often funny) history of the arts and politics of the 20th century, and an examination of a society in decline.  The protagonist's meetings with historical characters, from Picasso and Hemingway to the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, are surprisingly convincing and never seem like a \\"gimic.\\" I found the second half of the book somewhat less convincing than the first, and I got rather tired of the hero's obsession with his [physical] life, but all in all--a great read.  I will look for more William Boyd.

B000002KNI|5.0|One word sums up this incredible disk: transcendent.  I use superlatives sparingly, but I haul out the big guns for this gem.  Phenomenal.  Puts the others to shame.  There are SO many things important and interesting about this disk, and I say this as a rather tepid Simon and Garfunkel fan.  First, this disk is required listening for anyone who wants to produce a live performance- the sound is great, the arrangements are flawless, and it's evident that EVERYBODY, even the guys \\"selling loose joints\\" in the audience, are have one HELL of a time.  My guess is that there are a million people who claim to have been in that crowd of maybe sixty thousand.  Isn't that a telling index of success? Second, the recording retains all the charm of the video- I watched it countless times back when cable was in its infancy and the indefatigable rebroadcasts of HBO were still considered a novelty, and it was a great show that the recording captures marvelously.  The only things you don't get from the music are the drips of sweat from the drummer and the shots of Paul and Art obviously enjoying each other's company for the first time in years.  I take that back- the recording adequately conveys that fact as well.  Thirdly, the performance maintains fidelity to the original intent of all the songs (as far as they are expressed on their albums) while also adding a great live interpretation:  so often \\"live\\" albums fail because good songs sound [weak] or they don't sound anything like them to begin with.<br />This recording bridges the generations of those who grew up listening to Simon and Garfunkel when their albums first came out, those who clapped along while their parents watched the concert on cable television, and the young kids who consider the seventies and eighties to be the middle ages of modern culture.  Simon and Garfunkel have appeal beyond their milieu, and this is their seminal gift to modern pop music.

B00005JM09|3.0|Following on from the last installment of the film series - James Cameron`s groundbreaking Terminator 2: Judgement Day (1991) John Connor (Nick Stahl) is now in his 20`s living off the streets of present day LA - and a female Terminator called the T-X, or Terminatrix is sent back through time to kill John and also his future spouse Kate Brewster (a somewhat miscast and wooden Clare Danes, as her sole acting requirement appears to be to look frightened and scream). As before, a T-800 unit (Arnie) is also sent back to protect John....<br />Where do I start? As a standalone action piece, I enjoyed this film and thought it was great fun. Perhaps my expectations were set too high though when thinking of it as a `sequel` to the other parts - the setup is almost identical to T2 for one thing with basically the same story, just with a new, upgraded Terminator. This surely smacks of laziness.<br /><br />Brad Fiedel`s classic score, so synonomous with the two previous films in building up tension, is missing (though a new version of the famous theme is reprised at the end).<br />This film got a suprisingly lax 12A rating in Britain (compared to an R in the United States). It was perhaps due to a combination of all the killings happening offscreen and the lack of a recognisable, claustrophobic score (so we can know when the T-X is coming, for example) that made this film feel different. Where was the menace?<br />I never really got the feeling the T-X (a hot looking Kristanna Loken, who dresses in red leather) posed any real danger which was a shame - she lacks the cruel, sadistic nature of Robert Patrick in Terminator 2, or the `hunter` quality of Arnie in the first film, and of course looks like a catwalk model. Witness the gentle self parody of the scene where Arnie enters a strip club on `Ladies Night` - reaches into his leather jacket to put on his famous shades, and pulls out a pair of star shaped glasses Elton John would have worn in his 70`s heyday. Priceless.<br />There were some very good action scenes, including an unbelievable car chase that rivals a similar scene from The Matrix Reloaded, and some astounding effects.<br />The last act, and in particular the conclusion of the film, is brilliant. I won`t spoil the ending for you, but suffice to say it is remarkably downbeat for a Hollywood film, and more importantly remains true to the spirit of The Terminator franchise. Make no mistake, Jim Cameron`s ghost haunts this film, the ending recalling what he left behind.<br />Certainly not up to the standards of Cameron`s earlier classics in my opinion as its` less thought provoking and dark, but its` still a good film overall.there were some good jokes. The whole concept left me cold. What was the point of that whole episode except to waste another 30 minutes?<br />To top things off, the villain at the end had an excrutiatingly unclear motive as to why he'd go after Cruise's character. And while the PreCog division meets its unseemly demise at the end, there's no mention of the inevitable resumption of mass homicides. <br />For a movie that could have said a lot about motives and ambitions and how they are used and abused, instead we get MagLev chase scenes, jet-packs and Tom Cruise chasing his eyeballs down the hall.<br />Save your money and 2 hours and 20 minutes of your time.

B000021Y77|4.0|Have you ever had a dream where, perhaps you did not like the way the dream was evolving, so you manipulated the events in some sort of re-do/start-over variation, and tried again?  Well, this is 'Run Lola Run'...a heart-thumping, high adrenaline romp of a wild ride.<br />Lola is a young woman who is supposed to pick up her boyfriend, Manni, from the train station.  Manni - - who is kind of incompetent and obviously dependant on Lola for guidance - - works for criminal-types, and he was to make a delivery of 100,000 deutsche marks to his boss.  Due to circumstances beyond Lola's control, she is unable to pick up Manni at the designated time, and he, in his confusion, misplaces the bag which contains the money.  Manni is convinced that his boss will kill him if he doesn't have the money; Lola insists she can come up with the money, and Manni agrees to wait just twenty minutes for her, or else he will rob a large retail store nearby to get it.  The key here is the twenty minutes.  This frantic phone conversation sets everything in motion, and Lola's mad dash commences.  As the first twenty minutes winds down unsuccessfully, in that almost dream-like method, Lola is able to re-do the twenty minutes with similar but variant results, and then again a third time.  It is the variant results that make the scenes so fascinating.  Not only is this girl running with everything she's got, the director strafes you with fast-paced shots, and the pulsing techno-music feels like an aerobic workout in your brain.  Each person she comes across causes us to catch a small but interesting glimpse into the effects we all unknowingly have upon each other.  And, remarkably, for as little time you get with the lesser characters (her mother, father, people in the street), you are able to develop a much broader characterization and even a better understanding of who Lola is - - independent and confident.  <br />The only flaw in this story involves logic.  I couldn't help wondering why Lola just didn't go back and change the one thing that would've solved the whole situation - - get to the train station to pick up Manni on time!  But, all in all, I think 'Run Lola Run' is a very enjoyable film, and is visually pleasing as well as refreshingly original, story-wise.  I am just hoping it does not garner so much attention as to warrant an American copy, starring J-Lo!

B00008S2VG|5.0|Twenty years into her career the Material Girl still sets the pace.<BR>Last year marked the 20th anniversary of Madonna's debut single 'Everybody'. <BR>The former Ms Ciccone doesn't need to look very far to see her influence as a role model and fashion icon. Kylie Minogue, Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera and even Eminem may not bow down every night and thank Her Madge for paving the way for them but perhaps they should. <BR>With her imprint so deeply embedded in the DNA of pop it would be understandable if she decided to settle down with her hubby and kids, replay a few videos, remember the old times and relax. <BR>But American Life, a gloriously inventive, constantly surprising, deeply personal album, shows that rather than slowing down she's setting a pace that the young pretenders will be hard pushed to match.<BR>Production/writing partner Mirwais Ahmadzal has helped her create an audacious sonic landscape that matches cutting-edge cyber-dance techniques with prickly bruised guitars, gospel choruses, classical and operatic shading.<BR>Hollywood has a worldly-wise, funny lyric that skewers the shallowness of Tinseltown. The enthralling Nobody Knows Me is musically as imaginative as anything U2 or Radiohead have attempted.<BR>Religious references ( X-Static Process and the show stopping Mother and Father) run through the album. But even at her most serious and self-obsessed, Madonna never loses her sense of humour or feel for making life-affirming pop. She remains a colossus, with the competition left floundering in her wake.
B00006JL1Z|3.0|Fleetwood Mac released a Greatest Hits album in the late 1980s and a boxed set in 1993, so there was little more than a &quot;let's get into the act&quot; sense with this collection. Many classic artists are releasing two CD sets of their works, even some artists who already have a slew of greatest hits type compilations to their credit.<br />This set encompasses the work of Fleetwood Mac from their self-titled album of 1975 to their live reunion album The Dance, released in 1997. The only songs from any incarnation of the band besides the famous Rumours lineup are some easily-forgotten tunes from the days when Lindsey Buckingham left to explore his eccentricities. There are no songs from the pre-Buckingham Nicks days to speak of, no &quot;Sentimental Lady&quot; and certainly no &quot;Oh Well.&quot; That's where this set fails to impress.<br />Granted, there are some chestnuts here. &quot;Sisters Of The Moon&quot; is a forgotten jem of a song that just grabs your attention from the first listen. The original version of &quot;Silver Springs,&quot; a song that was previously relegated to the B-side of the &quot;Go Your Own Way&quot; single, is also here. However, what ISN'T here is what takes center stage.<br />Of course, &quot;Gold Dust Woman&quot; deserves to be in a &quot;best of&quot; compilation. However, instead of putting in &quot;Big Love,&quot; and the Rumours version of &quot;Gold Dust Woman,&quot; the band should have used the live version of &quot;Gold Dust Woman&quot; from The Dance video. Stevie Nicks's vocals are much more intense and angry in that live version, and would have added something great to this collection.<br />The first CD also has video of the band's recording of Say You Will, the first studio album with Lindsey Buckingham playing a key role since 1987's Tango In The Night. Unfortunately, not enough of that footage is there to warrant purchasing this set unless you're a completist.

0062502174|1.0|I wasn't engaged by the main character or the theme of finding one's \\"personal legend,\\" which was preached at the reader more than revealed. The book also lacked plot, rhythm and imagery to stimulate the imagination. I cannot fathom the popularity of this book. It does play into the basic human desire to find one's destiny. But it contains muddled, inconsistent and even contradictory spiritual themes centered on tapping into a universal life source. I actually recommend reading the book, for it portrays an increasingly prevalent world view that I'm afraid is based on wishful thinking. Following one's heart to fulfill a personal destiny is desirable. But history provides ample evidence that man's heart - while having potential - has instrinsic flaws. Other books of spiritual wisdom, including the Bible, are willing to tackle this challenge. Coehlo attempts to address it when the main character has a conversation with his heart. But ultimately, the author skirts the tough questions raised by his philosophy. I believe the author also diminishes his point by driving it home again and again through character after character and circumstance upon circumstance. At least it was a quick read. The casual reader may find some food for thought. But anyone with discernment will see this book for what it is -- warm, fuzzy spirituality crafted to appeal to non-critical thinkers. Apparently, Coehlo is still searching for truth. That's great, and it's a lot more than many of us are doing. I just wish he had proceeded a little further before penning this work.

She questions the Ph.D. specialists with \\"what ifs\\"---and it appears that a scientific hoax has been executed.<br />Whoever is behind the subterfuge is willing to wipe out the entire team of specialists to protect the lie with a Delta Force squad.<br />Tension, suspense, action and good old-fashioned skullduggery propel the flight to elude the assassins and uncover the mastermind behind the conspiracy.<br />With the findings of the latest (August, 2003) NASA investigations, it is remarkable how prophetic Dan Brown's fictional NASA is to the real thing.

B0000AI44Q|4.0|Greendale, which received much press -- some positive, most negative -- prior to release is a welcome return to form for a great artist. The 1990s were, quite surprisingly after the paltry 1980s, some of Neil Young's most artistically and commercially fruitful years. However, after releasing several great records in the early 1990s, Young seemed to lose focus. 1996's Broken Arrow was a solid, if unspectacular Crazy Horse Jam; 2000's Silver & Gold was seen as a career-defining moment for some, but many, including me, find it overrated; 2001's Are You Passionate? was a new twist but something less than a great album.     Greendale, on the other hand, is very good, if not quite great -- far and away Young's best release since Sleeps With Angels. Now, let this be said -- Greendale consists of exactly what Young's critics claim his music always is: an old hippie lamenting about how bad things are and how much better they used to be. For better or worse, Young has always played by his own rules. Greendale, though perhaps the most ambitious album of his entire career -- with its convoluted concept, long songs (even for Young), and accompanying multimedia projects -- is very spare musically and very, very, underproduced. The tracks consist entirely of Young's guitar (long-time Crazy Horse guitarist/keyboardist Frank \\"Poncho\\" Sampedro does not even appear), Billy Talbot's bass, and Ralph Molina's usual inept drumming, occasionally punctuated by Young's harominca and on one song by his organ; the only other devices are a megaphone (you'll see) and a lone voice over. This may be a concept album, but it isn't Pink Floyd's The Wall. The songs are carried almost entirely by lyrics; this is a very wordy album. Though most songs are long, and a few quite long, instrumental sections are generally short. But let it be said -- the words are very powerful and moving. Despite the elaborately detailed world Young has created -- just see his Web site for a taste of its complexity --, oneneed not concern oneself with its specifics. It may concern the Green family, but the story is univeral. Young chronicles emotions and sentiments that probably all of us have experienced. I almost cried listening to this album for the first time; no doubt many will go all the way. It is a very moving, very touching, very empathetic album. Young rouses emotions and makes us truly feel for the characters. As omniscient narrator, he seems distinctly bitter, almost against his will; the liner notes apologize several times for it not being a happy story. Here we find a man railing against crass modern materialism; just listen to Grandpa's rants and Sun's idealistic actions. The ending comes quite unexpectedly -- but, as Young says several times in the liner notes and also mentioned in a recent interview, our only hope lies in youth.     The album, though highly compelling and immensely interesting, is nevertheless imperfect. Though the lyrics are some of Young's finest in years, the music, as mentioned is not as strong as it has customarily been. Also, Young's voice has changed significantly in the last several years; he puts much-needed emotion and empathy into several songs -- notably \\"Bandit,\\" the album's best cut and the only one that stands out from the concept --, but he sings much of the album in a lazy sing-song way that makes it sound as if he's only half-interested. Despite these imperfections, however, Greendale is a vibrant, interesting, and affecting album that is Young's best in many years and an essential purchase for any fan.
B000003TAR|5.0|Within a year of finishing this album, Kurt Cobain was gone. He was another troubled soul who found that success made a failure of his life. The fame generated by Nevermind made his existance hell. In Utero was an intentionally 'difficult' album, an attempt to shake off the mainstream end of the fanbase, people who liked Bon Jovi but not Husker Du.<br />When first released, the album had that effect, with the controversial lyrical subject matter of tracks like Milk It (with the now-ironic lyric \\"look on the bright side of suicide\\") and of course Rape Me, and people finding it heavy, dark and perhaps depressive. However, herein lies the genius - within a few listens the true emotion and intensity comes forward.<br />Milk It is in fact my favourite, wtih a heavy guitar riff well used and some challenging lyrics. Frances Farmer Will Have Her Revenge on Seattle is a smart understated piece, with \\"I miss the comfort in being sane\\" another insightful wordplay. Very Ape and Tourette's are great to let off steam - although its sad that so many chancers now seem to think an album of Tourette's clones is 'real music'.<br />Usually I don't like Nirvana's slower efforts, but its not hard to appreciate why All Apologies was so popular. The use of acoustic guitar coupled with the grinding chorus is one of the most emotionally affecting tracks they ever recorded, and suggests that the album after this would've been spectacular. Alas, that was never to happen.

B000003TSP|4.0|Portishead had little to gain with this album. Their debut had been so successful that it shaped an entire musical style, and the whole landscape of a city. Their efforts to follow this were fraught, to the extent that almost an entire album was thrown away before they got this opne in the can.<br />All Mine and Only You are the most commercially palatable tracks on here, and 2 of the best. Beth is on top form vocally, a fact also borne out by the haunting Undenied. Only You brings the hip hop influence to the fore, sampling The Pharcyde to good effect and counter-balancing some of Beth's bleakest lyrics. All Mine's shimmering chorus is instantly memorable and balances well against the rest of the track.<br />Humming has to be seen as another standout, a six minute epic with builds from an eery intro to a passionate epochal climax. Anotehr favourite of mine is Western Eyes, which changes direction inexplicably at the end to provide a Portishead take on lounge, specifically the work of Shaun Atkins, described on the inlay as 'The Legend'.<br />However, in places the emphasis on atmospherics detracts a little form the tunes, and like any follow-up to an innovative debut, there is much less new ground to explore. I expect if you buy this first, you may end up preferring it, but I'd say Dummy stands above it.

B000002H8F|5.0|Yes, that description really is the only way I can do Bossanova justice. And just like previous efforts Surfer Rosa and Doolittle, this album is absolutely brilliant, even if it's a bit slickly produced for my taste.<br />Black Francis' twisted lyrics about incest and injury have been replaced by rather spacier, surfier stuff. No worries--Bossanova is still full of the trademark Pixies weirdness and the same brilliant use of quiet/loud dynamics (for a prime example listen to the explosive Down At The Well). After all, no other band could make a song as insane as Rock Music, especially preceded by the surf instrumental Cecilia Ann.<br />Joey Santiago's guitar playing is still wild and trebly, if a bit more melodic than before. Check out the neat, Talking Heads-esque riffs on Dig For Fire. Kim Deal contributes less than before unfortunately, but her backing vocals are put to good use here.<br />Every song is strong, but of special note are the brilliant epics All Over The World and The Happening. The latter is especially cool, weaving a haunting tale of aliens, Area 51, Las Vegas, and mass pilgrimage throughout its four minute run time. The last verse is delivered in an enchanting Shakespearean sonnet style. It might just be my favorite Pixies song of all time. Maybe...next to Where Is My Mind, River Euphrates, Tame, I Bleed, Monkey Gone To Heaven, Velouria, etc. etc. etc...I digress.<br />Don't believe the naysayers who say this is inferior to Surfer Rosa or Doolittle--Bossanova is EVERY bit as worthy. It is the last perfect Pixies album. The fourth (and final) album Trompe Le Monde is still very good, but lacks the consistency of previous releases. Overall Bossanova is a perfectly executed indie pop album, and essential to a true Pixies fan.

It's the 14th Century and evil queen Malificent curses Aurora, the king's infant daughter, taking away her happily-ever-after. Or so it would seem.<br />The brilliant interpretation of Tchaikovsky's ballet score and the distinctive medieval-inspired art of Eyvind Earle's detailed, pastel-hued, vertical-horizontal compositions, make this timeless romance -- based on a folk tale that arose after the Dark Ages (and a metaphor for the times?) -- a must-have for the digital family library and a masterpiece of animators' art. B00005JKHN|5.0|This movie is one of the great classics of animation, especially for Disney.  The DVD version is significantly improved compared to the previous VHS tape.  The picture and sound were both greatly enhanced for this release.  Furthermore, both widescreen and full screen versions are available in this package.<br />As with Disney's other classics, some liberties were taken with the original story of Sleeping Beauty.  Disney took the classic story and made it unique and special.  In some ways the story is less violent and dark than the original fairy tale.  In other ways, such as the portrayal of Maleficent, the movie is dark and forbidding.  While the movie is generally a children's movie, Maleficent's dragon and her general demeanor can be somewhat frightening for some in the pre-school and younger set.<br />Aurora was the first love for many a young boy, and was also the model for the aspirations of millions of girls.  The romantic love story of Princess Aurora and Prince Phillip enchanted would-be princesses everywhere, and in some cases became the measure by which future spouses were measured (and many of us struggled to meet the ideal).<br />Of course, the romantic story and the evil of Maleficent were balanced by the comedy of the animal characters and the three bumbling, good-hearted fairy godmothers.  While their goodness may appear a bit too vanilla and sweet for some, it is perfect for those longing for the innocence of their youth.<br />While the movie is the most important part of the DVD, this two CD set contains a phenomenal number of extras.  I found the audio commentary by various key individuals to be absolutely fascinating.  I planned to listen to portions of the commentary in preparation for my review, and instead found myself listening to the entire thing because it was so incredibly fascinating.  Mary Costa (Princess Aurora) and others provide their perspective on the creation of the movie, as well as personal memories of Walt Disney and his influence on the film.  The audio commentary by itself is worth replacing your VHS tape, particularly for aficionados of Disney movies.<br />In addition to the audio commentary are numerous, emphasize numerous, other bonus features.  Some I felt were less than worthwhile, others, such as the shorts \\"Grand Canyon\\" and \\"The Peter Tchaikovsky Story,\\" were excellent bonuses.  The number of bonuses on this two disc set was so large that there is a navigational overview included in the DVD that categorizes 38 features found on the second disc.<br />With the movie and the wealth of bonuses, this movie is a must-buy for those who have yet to have \\"Sleeping Beauty.\\"  For those who have the VHS, the bonus material is nearly worth the cost of the DVD.  Certainly those who are collectors of Disney memorabilia and historians of Disney will find the DVD to be a concise compendium of some of the best information available regarding this film.  I highly recommend this DVD!nce on the film. B000003CMB|5.0|This album is so hot, it would make the Devil jealous.  In the late '60s and early '70s, the pop/rock music scene discovered it wasn't limited to 2-1/2 minutes per song.  A lot of European bands did the Progressive Rock gig.  Genesis, Yes, ELP and others produced synthesizer heavy, very controlled fusion of classical music and rock/blues.  We Americans had the JAM session:  free form improvizational blues and rock.  This album is one of the finest examples of extended improvizational blues and one of the finest live albums ever.  At times, it is soft and saucy relying on Duane Allman's guitar, at other times, it is hard rolling highway music driven by the drums and bass.  A great and essential album.  \\"Lord have mercy!\\"<br />If you have a good surround system, preferably with well matched full range speakers, buy the DTS version.  While I am not totally happy with the mix-down engineer's choice of where to place the instruments (the lead guitar shouldn't be in the left rear channel), and I would like a two channel mix, all music, particularly of this quality, deserves better than the CD format.  CDs are harsh, brittle, synthetic, unnatural sounding and induce listener fatigue in minutes.  The DTS version returns all the richness of the original recording.  Sit back and enjoy!

Curtiz was the best action man at Warners.  Flynn was at his dashing best. Note how the camera pulls back and you see the sweep of the action--and this in the days before Cinemascope! B0000AXE8I|4.0|I'll make this clear from the start; I wasn't the hugest fan of the original Matrix movie. I thought it had good (but not great) action and a plot that sunk like a stone. As a result, I was fairly surprised to find that this installment was very well done and easy to watch, despite having several overly wordy and meaningless scenes like the first one did.<br />The movie chronicles the continuing adventures of a group of human rebels fighting to free the human race from the shackles of mental and physical imprisonment. One of the obligations of any sequel is that it ramp up what came before it, and this one does that in spades. The original bullet time fight scenes were impressive on their own; this time we're treated to such spectacles as hundreds of copies of a bad guy throwing themselves at one super-powered human, or an amazing freeway chase that runs about 15 minutes but only feels like 5 because it's so exciting. Action fans (especially martial arts fans) won't be disappointed here.<br />Though the plot is ignorable at best, the Wachowskis have successfully topped the original in about every way possible. B000089J0R|3.0|Dragonforce is an amazing band. Not one of their member is not a phenomenally skilled and talented musician. Don't bother with this album, though. Buy their 5-song demo, also titled Valley Of The Damned. It blows this album out of the water. Frankly, I was very excited to get this cd because usually demos are just that, demonstrations in preparation of what the real thing will be. Not so. The musicianship is still topnotch (with the exception of Starfire), but the mixing quality is terrible and not even consistent.<br />The title track, Valley Of The Damned, is so poorly mixed I actually winced. The demo version is the pinnacle of perfection as an example of what power metal should be. This recording is so badly mixed it hurt. The guitars overpower everything, the drums and bass are not audible and the vocals can barely be heard.<br />Black Fire, a new song, is excellent and mixed much better than the previous track, but the lyrics are derivative of Revelations. It is a good song, but not enough to save this album. Let's move on...<br />Black Winter Night is one of my favorite songs off the demo cd, but this version was poorly conceived and I'm not sure it can even really be called the same song. Only the intro, a portion of the verse and the breakdown are even the same. The chorus is entirely new; new song structure, new lyrics, etc. And it doesn't work. They turned what was an amazing song into a song that doesn't gel well, at all. If I hadn't heard the original version, I could have forgiven it but this just doesn't work.<br />Starfire, well let's just say they shouldn't even have bothered. The musician is not up to par, and it's played at a slower tempo than the original which, while not necessarily bad, ruins this. It almost feels as if the band was asleep while recording it.<br />Disciples of Babylon suffers somewhat from mixing problems, but overall is still excellent. There was some reworking of the song structure and lyrics, but the song remains rocking.<br />Revelations suffers from mixing problems, though strangely the instrumentation is mixed perfectly, the lead vocals are far too low in the mix and the backing vocals are at the proper level...that is if the lead vocals had been mixed properly. As it is, they drown out the leads. The song is still amazing, however. The plus to this recording of the song is that the keys are much more distinguishable in the mix than on the demo.<br />Evening Star, another new song, almost makes me feel like I can forget the faults this album has. The song is perfect. The mixing is near perfect. The dueling guitar solos, common to most every Dragonforce song, rise to a new level of musical skill. This is by far the shining jewel of the album.<br />Heart Of A Dragon, the last track and the final new song on the album, reminds me of something though what I can't say. It is good, but nothing special. It seems like a poor way to end the album. Maybe if it was tucked into the middle of the track listing somewhere, it wouldn't have mattered as much. This song just doesn't really do it for me somehow. Nothing wrong with it specifically, it's just not terribly inspired or original compared to their other works.<br />Overall, the cd is good...but not great. If more time had been spent in the studio at the mixing board and less trying to 'improve' already fantastic songs the thing would have been much better. It almost feels as if this was the demo piece, and their previous work the actual album. Sorry, Dragonforce; I love you, but this needs work. Worth the money for diehard fans only.br />Revelations suffers from mixing problems, though strangely the instrumentation is mixed perfectly, the lead vocals are far too low in the mix and the backing vocals are at the proper level...that is if the lead vocals had been mixed properly. As it is, they drown out the leads. The song is still amazing, however. The plus to this recording of the song is that the keys are much more distinguishable in the mix than on the demo.<br />Evening Star, another new song, almost makes me feel like I can forget the faults this album has. The song is perfect. The mixing is near perfect. The dueling guitar solos, common to most every Dragonforce song, rise to a new level of musical skill. This is by far the shining jewel of the album.<br />Heart Of A Dragon, the last track and the final new song on the album, reminds me of something though what I can't say. It is good, but nothing special. It seems like a poor way to end the album. Maybe if it was tucked into the middle of the track listing somewhere, it wouldn't have mattered as much. This song just doesn't really do it for me somehow. Nothing wrong with it specifically, it's just not terribly inspired or original compared to their other works.<br />Overall, the cd is good...but not great. If more time had been spent in the studio at the mixing board and less trying to 'improve' already fantastic songs the thing would have been much better. It almost feels as if this was the demo piece, and their previous work the actual album. Sorry, Dragonforce; I love you, but this needs work. Worth the money for diehard fans only.

038533348X|4.0|Like a lot of Vonnegut's works, the religious/scientific concepts and the fictional society of Cat's Cradle are more interesting than the story itself. However, this does not make the book in any way laborious to get through. You will chuckle to yourself many times, and probably even laugh out loud a couple of times. Vonnegut's talent for writing comical satire is certainly up there with Joseph Heller and the other greats; and Cat's Cradle lives up to what you'd expect from a master in his field. This book is a quick read (I read it all during a cross-country plane trip) and will both amuse you and also plant some wacky, but nonetheless ingenius, ideas into your head. Another good one by Vonnegut, it's worth it if you're a fan of his style or are just interested in getting acquainted with his work.

At each city or site he visits, he humorously recounts why its well known, who died there and why (for some odd reason, people keep setting out to cross the Outback and are never heard from or seen again), and what he found interesting about it. <br />Bryson points out the many dangers of Australia. Among them, of the ten deadliest snakes in the world, all ten happen to reside in Australia. For whatever reason, Bryson's writing style grabs you and pulls you. 0316921173|3.0|Let me say off the bat that before I even checked Wallace's shaggy dog story out of the library I had read many of the Amazon reviews, so I knew there was no hope for an ending, that none of the Ennnet House people ever run into the Enfield Tennis Academy people, and that the real protagonist is dead before the novel starts. Despite those problems, the novel reminded me of Thomas Mann's \\"Der Zauberberg\\" (The Magic Mountain) in that they are both \\"descriptive\\" novels of damaged people and their surroundings that barely move at all until their respective finales. However, \\"Infinite Jest\\" layers so many characters and subplots that the already sluggish book sputters to a stop, even though some of them are truly hilarious in a dark way (Lenz the addict, the child tennis player who threatens to blow his head off with a pistol unless he wins, the history of ONAN) and worse yet, none of them truly add to the story (except to increase the book's bulk.) Not until the 400th page did I figure out that this novel really wants to be an Internet hypertext document, on top of being a satire of sports novels and cyberpunk stories (the latter being really hip when this novel was written.) Early on I did like the \\"Royal Tenenbaums\\"-like vibe the book gave off as it described the environs of ETA and the bizarre, dysfunctional relationship the Incandenza family had toward each other and the charges of the academy, a vibe that wore off when I realized that - unlike the Tenenbaums - the Incandenzas play for keeps. I don't know if novels about train wrecks have to be train wrecks, but this novel of depression and addiction both sent me into deep funks and forced me to read it until the last page.
0767836324|5.0|I love grownup versions of classic children's stories, such as \\"Ever After\\" (a grownup Cinderella) and this movie, \\"Hook\\", a very grown-up Peter Pan.  \\"Hook\\" takes a sobering look at the downside of being \\"grownup\\"- our propensity for taking ourselves and our responsibilities far too seriously, forgetting how to have fun along the way, and how it harms our relationships with our families, especially our children.  Robin Williams as the grown-up Peter shows what a truly good actor he is in this movie, and that his comic genius is but one of his talents.  Dustin Hoffman, always a show-stealer, does not disappoint.  His \\"Hook\\" is at once funny and a very scary guy, at one point even killing the leader of the Lost Boys - this is definitely not your kids' Peter Pan.  The supporting cast do an excellent job as well.  <br />The visuals are imaginative and engaging, such as the child-pleasing bright crayon-colored foods at their banquets, and serve to remind us of how life is different through the eyes of a child - Bright green ketchup?  Cool! - and what fun it was to \\"think outside the box\\" before it was educated and conformed out of us.  Hook himself remembers this, and uses this knowledge to steal Peter's disillusioned son away from him, an act of revenge that forces Peter to re-learn the art of having fun in order to rescue him from the despicable Hook.  I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.<br />On a more serious note, \\"Hook\\" is a cautionary tale to which many of us \\"grownups\\" need to pay close attention, living in a society as we do that places (or should I say \\"misplaces\\") so much emphysis on providing material goods - the newest, the biggest, the brightest, the best of everything - that we are in real danger of neglecting the one and only thing our kids really need - our time - time for guidance, time for teaching, time for discipline, and time for just plain fun.  Hook is very real, and he manifests himself in terrifying ways - drugs, alcohol, sex, and the human predators that offer these to our children on a daily basis.  I am very glad I bought this video, because I can take it out and watch it any time life gets too serious and I need a reminder of what is really important.
B00008EY9G|4.0|Identity is a highly stylized and entertaining horror/thriller.  It is unusual to find a movie these days that manages to maintain both the horrific (with its attendant shock and gore) and the thrilling (with its adrenaline rushes and carefully measured plot revelations) elements, with out resorting to cheap and gratuitous tricks. That Identity manages to balance these competing forces and resist the urge to go over the top, definitely works in its favour.<br />That said, one of the most memorable things in this movie is John Cusack getting wet.  John Cusack gets wet like no other actor - he revels in rain. He mopes in a downpour like no other actor can, with his everyman act drenched in melancholy and drowning in the turmoil that lies just beneath the surface, the seething puddle of emotions barely contained beneath the glassy surface. John Cusack is an ocean of untold depths and as such he should be forced to stand out in the rain in every movie he does.  Sinking into the mud, there is no other actor that can portray the pain felt inside all of us like a wet John Cusack.  The gaunt face, the sunken eyes made even more pitiful by the stream of water running off his limp and sodden hair.  The clothes sticking uncomfortably to his emaciated body as thought he were the last rat to jump ship from the Titanic.  John Cusack gets wet very well, and given that this movie is set in a thunderous downpour in the Nevada desert, there are ample opportunities for John Cusack to leave the safe confines of his warm, dry motel room and get soaked to the bone.  I think this happens on at least 10 occasions, but I may have lost count at some point.  Somenody needs to by this kid an umbrella - if he dies of pneumonia, it'll be some lousy director to blame for all the untold hours hanging around movie sets damp and chilly.  Not since the classic &quot;High Fidelity&quot; has a movie given John Cusack as much opportunity to be washed out on screen and he obviously loves the opportunity to return to his aquatic home.<br />That said, Identity grabs you and draws you in.  This is not something you can keep on in the background while you do the dishes - unusually for many modern movies, it requires thought, attention and concentration, and in the end one is rewarded for noticing the small details and questioning things all along.  Some parts are a little predictable (the banana who leaves the bunch gets skinned...), and some go too much for the shock value (Baseball bat? NP!), although there is a fair amount of black humour to be found here (Mom and Pop both getting crunched in horrifically gratuitous car accidents while their already disturbed son looks on?).  And of course, without revealing too much of the plot, there's the courtroom drama playing out in Carson City at the same time.<br />Identity relies on three major twists.  The first of these is huge and brilliant - it comes totally out of leftfield at a time when the plot is on the verge of falling apart, and turns the movie from going bad to being bizarre (Do we need to introduce a plot twist with &quot;Isn't this like that movie where...?&quot;?).  The second twist is good, but you should've seen it coming for about 30 minutes.  The final twist is kind of silly, and for me brings the movie down from 5 stars to 4.<br />Overall I highly recommend this film - the characters are good, well developed and sympathetic, the plot is intelligent and gripping, and the cinematography and setting create a great, creepy mood (speaking as someone who has spent a lot of time in shady motels in Nevada, including the &quot;Shady Motel&quot;, Caliente Nevada...).  The ending leaves a little to be desired, but at least it's not usual Hollywood fodder, and for that we can be thankful.  Oh, and did I mention John Cusack gets wet?return to his aquatic home.<BR>That said, Identity grabs you and draws you in.  This is not something you can keep on in the background while you do the dishes - unusually for many modern movies, it requires thought, attention and concentration, and in the end one is rewarded for noticing the small details and questioning things all along.  Some parts are a little predictable (the banana who leaves the bunch gets skinned...), and some go too much for the shock value (Baseball bat? NP!), although there is a fair amount of black humour to be found here (Mom and Pop both getting crunched in horrifically gratuitous car accidents while their already disturbed son looks on?).  And of course, without revealing too much of the plot, there's the courtroom drama playing out in Carson City at the same time.<BR>Identity relies on three major twists.  The first of these is huge and brilliant - it comes totally out of leftfield at a time when the plot is on the verge of falling apart, and turns the movie from going bad to being bizarre (Do we need to introduce a plot twist with &quot;Isn't this like that movie where...?&quot;?).  The second twist is good, but you should've seen it coming for about 30 minutes.  The final twist is kind of silly, and for me brings the movie down from 5 stars to 4.<BR>Overall I highly recommend this film - the characters are good, well developed and sympathetic, the plot is intelligent and gripping, and the cinematography and setting create a great, creepy mood (speaking as someone who has spent a lot of time in shady motels in Nevada, including the &quot;Shady Motel&quot;, Caliente Nevada...).  The ending leaves a little to be desired, but at least it's not usual Hollywood fodder, and for that we can be thankful.  Oh, and did I mention John Cusack gets wet?
0471603864|5.0|David Griffiths' texts are indispensable for any beginner, and are used to &quot;translate&quot; more advanced texts.  I used his &quot;Quantum Mechanics&quot; to fill in the gaps at the advanced graduate level, and his &quot;Electrodynamics&quot; was essential to understanding Jackson. I'm sorry that I waited so long to purchase his &quot;Elementary Particles&quot;.<br />This book contains all the background that professors expect you to have already been exposed to: particle classification schemes, the November Revolution, relativistic kinematics, and fundamental force overviews.  Griffiths then goes on to discuss Feynman rules, QED, QCD, electroweak and gauge theories.  Griffiths also works out some essential problems, like muon decay, that you will want to see done, but I think it is done better by Lahiri and Pal (that, however, is a field theory book, which might be more advanced than is necessary to some people in particle physics).<br />This is a great text for anyone starting out in particle physics and for anyone who needs to review the fundamentals.  My only bone with Griffiths is that sometimes more of the work is left to the reader than is appropriate (those problems worked out in gory detail are a godsend when you genuinely aren't getting the point).

B0000AI44Q|4.0|Greendale is the new CD/DVD release from Neil Young and in this form attempts to momentarily freeze a work-in-progress that has evolved into a staged concert that is currently on tour. For having the courage to drive into this particular ditch at this stage of his life and career, rather than play it safe, I give Neil (it) a four star rating. Neil calls it a novel, and the DVD and accompanying  booklet provide the narrative structure on which the ten song cycle hangs. It is Thornton Wilder's &quot;Our Town&quot; meets Bruce Springsteen's &quot;Nebraska&quot;. Most of the songs are fairly long and because of the narrative dimensions of the lyrics are a bit sluggish at times. <BR>Greendale is also a Rorshach test for both Neil and us as his audience. Heaven knows which of our projections will come closest to being on target about what this all means. It is fun and quite a bit of work to absorb all this, and not since the Kinks released &quot;Preservation Act 2&quot; have we been taken on such a ride into the cosmic dimensions of the demise of the &quot;village green&quot; as seen through the eyes of a rock lyricist.<BR>There are heroes and villains a plenty, and the reminder that &quot;good and evil exist in all of us&quot;.<BR>Neil takes up the themes of environmental destruction, the role of the artist in the age of the internet, the human life span, the loss of privacy, and the role of good and evil in our lives while weaving in a few allusions to his own father/son relationship in the process. The clues are scattered about the booklet and DVD(which is an acoustic solo version of the music with Neil providing the story line between songs). He name drops Mr. Dylan and John Lennon and dreamily evokes &quot;the summer of love&quot; in the opening song.  Neil is at turns nostalgic and angry, as the story prompts us to reflect on where we are and where we have been as a culture since that summer of love. The music, which is mostly blues based, bogs down at times from the narrative elements of the tale which it has to bear. Positioned as Neil is, chronologically, between Grandpa Green and Sun Green we get to see life at both ends of the human/creative spectrum, but for me, not until he &quot;speaks&quot; through Sun Green's voice on the song of that name do we catch a glimpse into the emotional center of the artist responding to the current social crisis we find ourselves in.<BR>Neil offers no easy solutions, though he challenges us to become less passive and more active in resisting the evil that befalls us(via what comes dangerously close to sloganeering) in the CD's closer &quot;Be the Rain&quot;.<BR>If Greendale evokes in you a desire to check out another &quot;concept album&quot; I recommend the Kinks &quot;Preservation Acts 1 and 2&quot;, which covers some of the same ground, a bit more tunefully.
B00009W8N2|3.0|Opeth's first record kicks off with a bang, and by that I mean the first 2 minutes on the first track is without a doubt one of the (best)...metal riffs in history. As soon as that's over though, you get pushed into a 14 minute song that's about 3-4 minutes too long. That's ok though, this is Opeths debut, I mean, I could never write a song like this. Track 2 is good but also has one long slow interlude in the middle that seems to just take too long, the acoustics toward the end are gorgeous though. Anyways, the rest of the record has it's ups and downs and are spread apart about 50/50. half good, half not so good. You do get treated to some INCREDIBLE music here though, like track 3, Silouette, an instrumental 3 minute piano ballad that'll leave your jaw dropped by its incredible charisma, breathtakingly beautiful rhythems and imaginative creativity. It's almost like some genious piece of work Mozart or Beethoven would write. Anyways, on to track 4 which is a little boring so I always skip it. The rest of the tracks on the record do have thier moments, mostly during the acoustic interludes which are beautifully written but overall the songs aren't very fulfilling. It's a very instrumental record, whereas while vocals go on for a few minutes, you'll then get treated to about 4 or 5 minutes of instrumentals before the vocals come back again. It's a very black metal record apart from the acoustics. Another downfall I should mention is that after a while the vocals on the record do become somewhat irritating, there is almost no clean singing on this one and mostly loud screeching growls. I mean, growls are cool and Opeth is known to utilize both singing methods but on this record it seems to go overboard with the growls. They're not even really growls but more high pitched yells that after a while start to annoy. Opeth did seem to learn from this though and now tone it down and add an equal variety of clean vocals within the music. <BR>In conclusion I should say that die hard Opeth fans are the only ones who'll really \\"get\\" this album, whereas newcomers by my suggestion should NOT buy this as their first Opeth record but pick up the later, more memorable genious works like Blackwater Park, Still Life, or Damnation. All hail Opeth, the riegning KINGS of metal!

0316666343|1.0|I agree with one reviewer already posted on two points. Firstly, the emotional impact of Susie Salmon's rape and murder is a bit lessened by the ridiculous detail of her elbow being found. How likely is that? Maybe I'm just a stickler for detail, but an elbow is extremely difficult to detach from the body. Secondly, the manner of Susie's murderer's death is trite and silly. It undoes the author's hard work at creating suspense around his capture. I would add that the dialoges between the characters seem completely unrealistic, especially those between young people. As I recall, love affairs in middles school were less than touchy, sentimental affairs. They were confused, superficial, and awkeward and usually did spell the beginning of life long romance. I guess what I was missing in the portrayal of youth and basically in all the characters (save the serial killer, of course) was the dark side. Everyone is so nice to each other and says all the right things (albeit in short, clipped sentences) even at the ages of 13 and 14. Whatever dark emotions are felt by the characters are never expressed in dialogue but rather by completely radical acts like hunting people in corn fields with baseball bats and running away to California. I had the feeling the Salmon family was a bit autistic. Are we to believe that that is what the death of a loved one does to us? Even Susie herself is amazingly even tempered considering the rage one would expect her to have. As another reviewer also pointed out, she sqanders her time on earth to have sex instead of revealing the location (which the omniscient Susie has seen) of her murderer. Not only is that a bit difficult to believe but makes her morally culpable in his future killings. Also, what kind of heaven are we talking about where people don't have sex? I think I'll close by saying that I found the author's description of heaven a bit claustrophobic and creapy. Why or why would she have wanted a carbon copy of her school in heaven? Why is she seemingly alone most of the time except for one depressing little girl and a murder counselor? It was implied that she wasn't in heaven proper yet because she hadn't let go. Catholics call this purgatory. Oh well. I guess that doesn't have the same ring to it as heaven. Reading this book was like being in purgatory. That about sums it up.
B000062Y98|4.0|This was the first Blind Guardian cd I've ever purchased, I was originally interested in them after seeing the beautiful artwork on the \\"Nightfall on Middle Earth\\" CD. This record though was actually one I was able to sample at a local store. Upon first listen the top word that popped in my head was CHEESY. The music in this isn't like the typical metal out there that gets thrown in your face all over TV and radio. It's very epic, very operatic, very symphonic, and very progressive. It's almost like a modern day louder, faster Queen, or what metal would've sounded like had it been around during victorian Ireland. The only other power metal I've been exposed to are Symphony X and Dream Theater. Blind Guardian is still progressive but not in the typical power metal way Sym X or Drm Thtr are. The guitars aren't as thick and BG incorporates vocals from what seems to be all the band's members, and they can all sing REALLY  well I might add. <BR>So I was open enough to listen to it the whole way through, I thought it was pretty good at first, then I gave it a few more listens and I only liked it more and more. There is just sooo much on this record you pick up new things the more times you listen to it. All the songs aren't too long or too short, most falling in the 5-7 minute area, the guitar playing is superb, the melodies entrancing, the catchy vocals and choruses will have you singing along and getting these songs stuck in your head for a good while afterward. At first you may think this is pretty headache inducing, noisy, and too abstract just as I did. But the more chances you give it the more the songs make sense, the more they fall together and the more structure you begin to understand. The album also contains 2 of what I've decided to be in my top 5 favorite songs EVER-\\"Maiden and the Minstral Knight\\" and \\"Waiting for an Answer.\\" I agree slightly with a fellow review who said this is a flawed masterpiece. Yes, it is flawed, but very very slightly. I took off 1/2star only because, like I said, this album isn't perfect, there are about 2 songs on this record I can't listen too a lot because they sound both a bit dragged (although they do have their great moments). A lot of people will disagree with me on this but that's just me, though I can say I do appreciate these songs for their depth and talent, or else I would've delete 1 or more stars. 2 songs is still a significant amount to delete 1/2 star. <BR>...I would say one must be more familiar with different forms of metal and that they all aren't consistent riffs and grunts, screams, etc as seen all over the media. This is epic prog metal at some of its finest. Those who are mature enough to understand the genre I highly recommend this record to, given enough time, I guarantee it'll be spinning on your cd player for a long time to come.

0688163173|4.0|Dennis Lehane's psycho thriller Shutter Island is set in the 1950's around the Boston area.  U.S. Marshal Teddy Daniels, a tough hard boiled WWII veteran is ordered to Shutter Island along with his new partner Chuck Aule to investigate the disappearance of an inmate of the Ashecliffe Hospital which located on the island.  Ashecliffe is a mental facility for the criminally insane.<br />Daniels soon learns that the patient, Rachel Solando, a triple child murderess has inexplicably vanished without a trace.  The hospital staff lead by a brilliant but mysterious Dr. Cawley is less than helpful in aiding the marshals.  As a hurricane bears down on the island stranding Daniels and Aule, the marshals make some startling discoveries.  They suspect that Ashecliffe is secretly being used for both surgical and pharmacologic experimentation on the inmates.<br />Daniels, who was an intelligence agent in the war, finds and deciphers clues apparently left behind by Solando to unravel the mysteries of Shutter Island.<br />Lehane's novel progresses along fluidly until it makes an abrupt and somewhat clumsy twist into a &quot;I can't believe he ended it like this&quot; conclusion.
6305897786|4.0|Rewatching this movie recently I was struck by how much it improves upon subsequent viewings. The subtle nuances of Johnny Depp's performance reveal themselves only to confirm that he is definitely one of the greatest living actors working today.<br />It's easy to see why mainstream audiences stayed away from this movie. There is an uneasy mix of playful, black humour and serious dread throughout that constantly keeps the viewer off balance -- in a good way. Also, Depp plays a decidedly unlikable character -- right from the start, where he screws a hapless family out of rare, expensive books, establishes that he is an unscrupulous book dealer only in it for the money. However, Depp's own natural charisma maintains interest in his character and even makes him kinda sympathetic in a weird way as he gradually realizes that he is in way over his head.<br />The use of European locations is excellent and effectively establishes an atmospheric vibe that gets me every time. It doesn't hurt that the film is shot by DP extraordinare, Darius Khondji (Seven). Every frame of this movie is beautifully shot.<br />The DVD itself is pretty good. The extras are a bit on the slim side with a superficial (and extremely brief!) Making Of featurette but the real crowning touch is an audio commentary by the man himself, Roman Polanski. He starts off a little slow but once he gets going, offers quite a few interesting tidbits and views on filmmaking (and, of course, the movie itself) and is definitely worth a listen for Polanski fans.<br />This is an underrated film that is definitely worth a look if you like something a little different in your films. It doesn't hold your hand like most Hollywood fodder does and this a refreshing change.

0385504209|2.0|After all the hyperbole surrounding The Da Vinci Code, I was expecting to read a well written, thoughtfully chacterized and enlightening book. In its favor it must be said that this novel is definitely a page-turner. The action is fast paced and there is lots of it. However, that is part of the problem. The action is so fast, and much of it so far fetched, that the story strays dangerously into the realm of the brainless &quot;beach book&quot; written with a movie version as its ultimate goal. The characters are very thinly drawn and virtually caricatures of themselves - the beautiful French woman, the dry and dreamy academic, the physically repulsive hit man, the overly English Englishman, the predictable red herring in the form of the tough French police officer - it all strains credulity. The language which Dan Brown puts in his characters' mouths does not ring true and detracts from what could have been a far more appealing book. There are some truly interesting ecclesiastical triviata, observations and theories in the story, but they are dished up with a pretentiousness which renders them indigestible. Dan Brown gives in to the temptation to lecture his readers far too often. The twists and turns in the plot are too predictable and tidy to be surprising and they are dressed up in somewhat patronising terms. I don't plan on giving any of the secrets away, but the sleight of hand with which the author neatly ties up his loose ends strays dangerously near to being laughable. Evidently a great deal of research went into the writing of the book and the underlying premise is both clever and fascinating, it is therefore a pity that an editor did not work with Mr. Brown to smooth out the presentation and make this the genuinely clever novel which it could have been.<br />If you are looking for an easy summer read then this fits the bill, but don't be taken in by the talk of true mysteries, religious controversy and academic puzzles. This is a reasonably entertaining thriller, nothing more.ller, nothing more.
6305232660|1.0|DO NOT READ THIS REVIEW if you can forgive a science fiction film for a lot of bad science. But if you are an astronomy buff like me, take this review as fair warning.<br />I had SUCH high hopes for this movie. \\"At last!\\" I thought, \\"They're finally making a scientifically-accurate film about a cometary impact!\\" And check out that poster! Looks like The End Of The World, for sure! COOL!<br />So I shelled out my money and sat down in the dark theater to watch \\"Deep Impact,\\" and within ten minutes I had started to squirm. \\"You can't predict a comet's path that far in advance!\\" I wanted to scream at the screen. Then the astronomer who discovers Earth is doomed gets KILLED in a car crash, and evidence of his discovery goes flying out the window on a diskette! I guess this was for dramatic effect.<br />But wait! The diskette must have been found, because now there's a secret project to move some select people deep underground, presumably to rebuild civilization after the comet hits. Except that we never get to see any of these immense underground warrens. Probably would've taken the picture over budget.<br />Then the smaller half of the comet hits the Atlantic Ocean, resulting in some interesting CGI. But if the larger half of the comet strikes, then civilization is most certainly doomed. What kind of a world will the underground survivors emerge to find? THAT would have made for a visionary science fiction film. But NO, we won't be treated to that, because at the very end the apocalyptic object is blown up by some heroic astronauts, and all the millions of fragments burn up harmlessly in the atmosphere. HARMLESSLY??? Hmmm, in real life the kinetic energy of the comet would still remain, and standing under the open sky would've have been like being in an oven set to BROIL. But that wouldn't have been a very crowd-pleasing ending, now would it?<br />Remember when the beautiful Comet Hale-Bopp lit our evening skies? Remember when Comet Shoemaker-Levy took bites out of Jupiter? If either of those objects had struck Earth, we'd be lucky to have bacteria left. This is one of the reasons we MUST begin branching out from beyond our own planet. Our survival as a species depends on this. And perhaps one day a truly visionary film director will create a movie that deals with this scenario more realistically, but \\"Deep Impact\\" is not that movie. For all its introspection about how humankind might deal with its impending doom, \\"Deep Impact\\" is bad astronomy and bad science.ter?
